titlepage.titleproper: Register of the Vasilii Maklakov Papers, 1881-1956
titlepage.publisher:
Hoover Institution Archives
Stanford University
Stanford, California
titlepage.p: © 1998 Hoover Institution Archives. All rights reserved.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, reports, diaries, and clippings, relating to Russian foreign relations with France, the Bessarabian territorial question, the Russian Revolution, and Russian emigres in France after the revolution.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Vasilii A. Maklakov Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1957.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born, Moscow, Russia. Son of A. N. Maklakov, Professor at Moscow University
Attended Moscow University. Was expelled for political activity but reinstated and received diploma in history
Received law degree and began private law practice in Moscow Elected member of Moscow Law Society
Elected as a representative of Moscow to Second State Duma and reelected to Third and Fourth Duma Active member of Kadet Party
Appointed Russian Ambassador to France by the Provisional Government at which post he remained until France officially recognized the Soviet Union

Headed the Emigre Committee and Central Office in France dealing with all matters relating to Russian emigres in France and the French Government Member of the Nansen International Office for Refugees in Geneva
Author of Vlast' i Obshchestvennost' na zakate staroi Rossii
Author of Rechi: sudebnyia, dumskiia i publichnyia lektsii,1904-1929

scopecontent.p: Autobiographical sketches and diaries. Arranged alphabetically by physical form.

Personal and political correspondence, especially with colleagues in the political arena, including A. Kerenskii, B. Bakhmetev, E. Sablin, and others. Also includes official correspondence with French government officials regarding Russian and emigre matters. Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.
Books, speeches, public lectures and book reviews by V. Maklakov. Arranged chronologically by title.

orrespondence, essays and printed matter related to Russian Embassy business, including negotiation at Paris Peace Conference on the question of Bessarabia and Boris Savinkov and Russkii Evakutsionnyi Komitet v Pol'she. Also includes writings by V. Maklakov and other material related to Russian emigre affairs in France, especially during World War II. Arranged alphabetically by subject.
Includes clippings of writings by V. Maklakov, especially in Russian emigre press, and notebooks of clippings dealing with Russian and emigres affairs, arranged for V. Maklakov by subject.
Cartoons, map, posters, and flags related to World War I. Arranged alphabetically by physical form.
